Option B. One infant is atavistic: Atavism refers to the appearance of characteristics found in distant ancestors but not observed in recent generations. It does not apply to paternity.

 

Option D. One infant is suppositious: Suppositious refers to something that is fraudulently substituted. This term does not explain the situation of having different fathers for twins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Superfecundation is the fertilization of two ova in the same menstrual cycle by sperm from different partners, explaining how twins can have different fathers.

 

Ref: Page no 2188, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4, E-5
A-1, B-5, C-3, D-2, E-4
A-1, B-2, C-2, D-3, E-4
A-2, B-1, C-3, D-4, E-5

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-1, B-5, C-3, D-2, E-4

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Yolk Sac Tumor is associated with AFP, Choriocarcinoma with Beta hCG, Epithelial Cell Tumor with Ca125, Granulosa Cell Tumor with Inhibin, and Dysgerminoma with LDH.

 

Ref: Page no 521, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology

questions.text: In a clinical study exploring the relationship between variables X and Y, a scatter plot with a linear regression line has been generated. Based on the graphical representation provided, which of the following equations corresponds to the linear regression model of the plotted graph? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) y=11+2x

 

  • Y = 11 + 2x is a simple linear regression equation where a = 11 and b = 2 are constants and x and y are variables.
  • Regression is change in measurements of a variable. It provides structure of relationship between 2 quantitative variables.

 

Types of regressions:

 

  • Simple linear regression: Only one dependent variable and one independent variable
  • Multiple linear regression: Only one dependent variable and more than one independent variable
  • Simple curvilinear regression: Only one dependent variable and one independent variable, with some power of independent variable
  • Multiple curvilinear regression: Only one dependent variable and more than one independent variables, with some power of independent variables).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of regression equations:

questions.text: The strict anaerobe among the following is: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prevotella

 

The strict anaerobe in the given options is Prevotella.

 

Prevotella spp are anaerobic, gram negative bacilli or coccobacilli.

 

Prevotella spp. are members of the oral, vaginal, and gut microbiota and are often recovered from anaerobic infections of the respiratory tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Burkholderia cepacia:  Is gram-negative, aerobic bacilli belonging to pseudomonad group.

 

Option B. Yersinia enterocolitica: Are gram negative facultative anaerobes.

 

Option C. Stenotrophomonas maltophilia: Are gram-negative, aerobic bacilli belonging to pseudomonad group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prevotella species are strict anaerobes, thriving in oxygen-free environments, and are part of the normal flora of the oral, vaginal, and gut microbiota. They can be involved in various anaerobic infections, particularly of the respiratory tract.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Entry of calcium into sarcoplasmic reticulum

questions.text: Myosin head detaches from actin by which of the following mechanism? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Binding of ATP

 

Binding of ATP on the free site of myosin leads to the detachment of myosin head from the thin filament.

 

 

Energy for movement of myosin head (power stroke) is obtained by breakdown of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) into adenosine diphosphate (ADP) and inorganic phosphate (Pi). Head of myosin has a site for ATP and itself can act as the enzyme ATPase and catalyse the breakdown of ATP.

 

Even before the onset of contraction, an ATP molecule binds with myosin head.

When tropomyosin moves to expose the active sites, the head is attached to the active site. Now ATPase cleaves ATP into ADP and Pi, which remains in head itself. The energy released during this process is utilized for contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Entry of calcium into sarcoplasmic reticulum: Incorrect. The entry of calcium into the sarcoplasmic reticulum helps in muscle relaxation but does not directly cause the detachment of the myosin head from actin.

 

Option C. Change in troponin C configuration: Incorrect. The change in troponin C configuration exposes the active sites on actin for myosin binding but does not cause detachment.

 

Option D. Release of ADP and Pi: Incorrect. The release of ADP and Pi occurs after the power stroke but does not cause the detachment of the myosin head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The detachment of the myosin head from actin is caused by the binding of ATP to the myosin head, which is a critical step in the muscle contraction and relaxation cycle.

choices.text: Heat coagulation test

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic with fatigue, dizziness, and recent weight loss. She mentions that she has been following a very restrictive diet for the past two weeks, consuming very few calories each day. On physical examination, she appears slightly dehydrated, with sunken eyes and dry mucous membranes. Blood glucose levels are normal, but a dipstick urine test reveals the presence of ketone bodies. Which urine test is most commonly used to detect ketone bodies in a starvation state?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Rothera’s test

 

Explanation:

 

Rothera’s test is the standard test used to detect ketone bodies in urine, which commonly appear during states of increased ketogenesis such as starvation, prolonged fasting, or uncontrolled diabetes. The test involves adding sodium nitroprusside and ammonium sulfate to the urine sample; the formation of a purple ring indicates the presence of acetoacetate and acetone, two key ketone bodies. Ketone bodies are produced when fatty acids are broken down for energy due to insufficient carbohydrate intake, leading to ketonuria, which is often seen in starvation, ketogenic diets, or diabetic ketoacidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Benedict’s test: Benedict's test detects reducing sugars in urine, such as glucose, fructose, and lactose. It is commonly used in the diagnosis of conditions like diabetes mellitus but does not detect ketone bodies.

 

Option B. Heat coagulation test: The heat coagulation test is used to detect the presence of proteins in urine. When the urine is heated, proteins precipitate, forming a cloudy appearance, which is seen in conditions such as nephrotic syndrome or other kidney disorders. It is not used for ketone body detection.

 

Option D. Sulfosalicylic acid test: This test is used to detect proteins in the urine by causing protein precipitation, indicating proteinuria. It is not useful in identifying ketone bodies, making it irrelevant for detecting ketosis or ketonuria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rothera’s test is specifically used to detect ketone bodies in the urine, which are commonly present in conditions such as starvation, prolonged fasting, and diabetic ketoacidosis. Understanding this test helps identify metabolic states that induce ketogenesis, aiding in the appropriate management of patients with these conditions.

choices.text: Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm
Urgently wheel the patient to OT for surgery
Surgery is indicated only if aneurysm is > 70mm

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient, during his routine annual checkup, is found to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 40 mm in diameter on USG abdomen. Which of the following is true about the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm

 

Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm: True. Generally, surgery (either open surgical repair or EVAR) is recommended for asymptomatic male patients when the AAA reaches a diameter of 5.5 cm (55mm) or greater. The risk of rupture increases significantly as the diameter surpasses this threshold, so this is the currently accepted cutoff for intervention in many guidelines.

 

Surgery is indicated in asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm only if its diameter is more than 55mm.

 

If the diameter is less than 55mm, regular ultrasound monitoring is required. This is because elective open surgery has a higher rate of mortality when compared to conservative management for aneurysms of size <55mm.

 

Other Options:

 

The size of an AAA determines the risk of rupture, and this risk informs the decision for surgical intervention.

 

Option A. Urgent endovascular aneurysm repair: Not necessarily true for a 40mm AAA. Endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) is a less invasive method than open surgery, but it is not typically done urgently for aneurysms of this size unless they are symptomatic or rapidly increasing in size.

 

Option C. Urgently wheel the patient to OT for surgery: Not true for a 40mm AAA. As the aneurysm is still below the general threshold for surgical intervention, there's no need for urgent operation unless there are other complicating factors (e.g., rapid growth or symptoms).

 

Option D. Surgery is indicated only if aneurysm is >70mm: Not true. Waiting for an AAA to reach 70mm before considering surgery would expose the patient to a very high risk of rupture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Surgery (open surgical repair or EVAR) is recommended for asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysms when the diameter reaches 55mm or greater due to the increased risk of rupture beyond this size. Regular monitoring is advised for smaller aneurysms.

choices.text: Non-Hodgkin lymphoma
Bronchogenic Carcinoma
Germ cell tumor

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient is diagnosed with pure red cell aplasia and a mediastinal mass. Which of the following can be the likely cause? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thymoma

 

Thymoma is the most likely diagnosis for the clinical presentation of a mediastinal mass with pure red cell aplasia.

 

Pure red cell aplasia (PRCA) is a rare syndrome characterized by a selective failure of erythroid element production in the bone marrow but normal granulopoiesis and megakaryocytopoiesis.

 

The patients have normocytic normochromic anemia, with normal granulocyte and platelet counts. Reticulocytes are significantly reduced or absent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Non-Hodgkin lymphoma:

 

Association: While lymphomas can present as mediastinal masses and may cause cytopenias, they are not specifically associated with pure red cell aplasia.

 

Option C. Bronchogenic Carcinoma:

 

Association: Bronchogenic carcinoma typically presents with respiratory symptoms and does not have a known association with PRCA.

 

Option D. Germ cell tumor:

 

Association: Germ cell tumors can present as mediastinal masses but are not specifically linked to PRCA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thymoma is the most likely cause of a mediastinal mass in a patient with pure red cell aplasia. PRCA is characterized by a selective deficiency of erythroid precursors in the bone marrow, leading to severe anemia with normal granulocyte and platelet counts, and is often associated with thymoma.

questions.text: Which gene is not involved in double strand DNA break repair mechanism? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MSH2

 

MSH2 stands for "MutS homolog 2." The gene is located on chromosome 2 and is not directly involved in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks. Instead, MSH2 is a key component of the DNA mismatch repair (MMR) pathway. MMR is responsible for correcting errors that occur during DNA replication, such as mismatches and small insertions or deletions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. BRCA1: BRCA1 (Breast Cancer 1) is involved in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks through the homologous recombination pathway. Mutations in the BRCA1 gene are associated with an increased risk of breast and ovarian cancers.

 

Option C. KU70: KU70, along with KU80, forms the Ku heterodimer (Ku70/Ku80), which is a crucial component of the non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) pathway. NHEJ is a major mechanism for repairing double-strand DNA breaks, especially in the G1 phase of the cell cycle.

 

Option D. ATM: The ATM (ataxia-telangiectasia mutated) gene codes for a protein kinase that plays a central role in the cellular response to double-strand DNA breaks. It activates a signaling cascade that leads to DNA repair and cell cycle control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 understand the roles of different genes and proteins in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks (DSBs), which is essential for maintaining genome stability and preventing mutations.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to a tertiary care hospital in India with a history of fatigue, unexplained weight loss, and persistent cough for the last six months. He has a 20-pack-year smoking history but quit five years ago. Physical examination reveals pallor and mild hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigations, including complete blood count, show anemia. A biopsy of a liver lesion is performed, revealing evidence of abnormal gene expression regulation, particularly in genes involved in cellular proliferation and apoptosis. The pathologist explains that these changes are not due to mutations in the DNA sequence but rather alterations in gene accessibility and chromatin structure. Which of the following processes is most likely responsible for this abnormal gene regulation?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) DNA methylation
 

Explanation:


DNA methylation is a key epigenetic modification involving the addition of methyl groups to cytosine residues in DNA, typically leading to suppression of gene activity by condensing the chromatin and restricting access to transcription factors. In the clinical scenario, the description of altered gene expression without direct mutations aligns with epigenetic changes like DNA methylation, which commonly leads to reduced gene expression by silencing gene promoters.
 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Histone acetylation: This process involves the addition of acetyl groups to histones, leading to a relaxed chromatin state and increased gene expression, which is the opposite effect seen in the patient’s case.
 

Option C) Point mutation: This involves direct alterations in the DNA sequence itself, unlike the described epigenetic modifications that do not change the DNA sequence but rather affect gene expression indirectly.
 

Option D) Gene duplication: This process involves an increase in the number of gene copies, which could lead to increased gene expression, but it does not match the mechanism of epigenetic regulation described in the scenario.
 

Educational Objective:


Epigenetic modifications such as DNA methylation and histone acetylation regulate gene expression without altering the DNA sequence. DNA methylation typically suppresses gene expression, whereas histone acetylation enhances it by modifying chromatin accessibility. These modifications can be influenced by environmental factors and contribute to disease development without direct genetic mutations.

choices.text: It has multiple reducing ends
It can be stored at multiple organs
It can provide glucose for about 1 week when needed

questions.text: Glucose is stored in the form of glycogen because? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is compact

 

Glycogen is a multibranched polysaccharide of glucose that serves as a form of energy storage in animals, fungi, and bacteria. It is the main storage form of glucose in the human body as it is compact.

 

In humans, glycogen is made and stored primarily in the cells of the liver and skeletal muscle. Liver glycogen helps to maintain the blood glucose levels in the fasting state. Most of the liver glycogen gets depleted after 18hrs of fasting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It has multiple reducing ends: Glycogen has multiple non-reducing ends, which facilitate rapid mobilization of glucose, not reducing ends.

 

Option C. It can be stored at multiple organs: Glycogen is mainly stored in the liver and skeletal muscles, not in multiple organs.

 

Option D. It can provide glucose for about 1 week when needed: Liver glycogen stores are typically depleted after about 18 hours of fasting, not 1 week.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen is stored in a compact form, allowing efficient storage of large amounts of glucose in liver and muscle cells, enabling rapid mobilization of glucose when needed.

questions.text: Which of the following Amino acid needs to be supplied in the diet of patients with Cystathionine beta synthase defect? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cysteine

 

Cysteine is not typically restricted in the diet of patients with CBS deficiency. In fact, cysteine supplementation may be necessary in some cases because CBS deficiency can lead to a decreased ability to convert homocysteine into cysteine. However, this decision is made on an individual basis after assessing the patient's specific needs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methionine: Methionine is usually restricted in the diet of patients with CBS deficiency. Since methionine is metabolized to homocysteine, limiting dietary methionine intake can help reduce homocysteine levels in these patients.

 

Option C. Serine: Serine is not typically restricted in the diet of CBS-deficient patients. It is not directly related to homocysteine metabolism, so it does not require special dietary adjustments.

 

Option D. Homocysteine: Homocysteine is not supplied in the diet but rather accumulates in the body as a result of CBS deficiency. Managing and reducing elevated homocysteine levels is the primary goal of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystathionine beta synthase (CBS) is involved in the synthesis of cysteine from dietary methionine. Cysteine synthesis require methionine, serine and vitamin B6. The reactions are summarized in the diagram:

 

 

So, in case of CBS deficiency there will be no formation of cystathionine and cysteine. so, cysteine becomes essential and needs to be taken in diet.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 291

questions.text: A couple with 2 children who are not able to conceive for over an year now present to the OPD. The male partner is diagnosed to be having hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism. Which of the following is not true? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Low prolactin levels

 

Explanation:

 

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism in males is characterized by a deficiency of gonadotropins (LH and FSH), which leads to low testosterone levels and impaired spermatogenesis. This condition often results in oligospermia or azoospermia, contributing to infertility. Additionally, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is frequently associated with hyperprolactinemia rather than low prolactin levels.

 

  • Low LH and FSH: Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is marked by low levels of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) due to inadequate secretion from the pituitary gland.
  • Low testosterone: The low levels of LH lead to reduced stimulation of Leydig cells in the testes, resulting in low testosterone levels.
  • Oligospermia: The low levels of FSH result in impaired spermatogenesis, often leading to oligospermia or azoospermia.
  • Low prolactin levels (Incorrect): Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is associated with hyperprolactinemia, not low prolactin levels. Elevated prolactin can inhibit the secretion of gonadotropins, further exacerbating the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low LH and FSH: True. Gonadotropin deficiency is a hallmark of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Option B. Low testosterone: True. The deficiency in LH leads to low testosterone production.

 

Option C. Oligospermia: True. The deficiency in FSH leads to impaired spermatogenesis, causing oligospermia or azoospermia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A male with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism will have high prolactin levels, low gonadotropins (LH and FSH), low testosterone, and often oligospermia or azoospermia.

 

Ref: Page no 199, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

choices.text: Uterine artery embolization

questions.text: A 33-year-old female patient comes with complaints of menorrhagia for the past 3 months. The duration and regularity of her menstrual cycles are normal. Non- hormonal management has been tried without success. What is the most appropriate next step? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hormonal therapy

 

Explanation:

 

  • Hormonal therapy is the next best management modality for menorrhagia when non-hormonal management has failed. This includes combined oral contraceptive pills or even progesterone-only devices like the LND-IUS.
  • First-line management includes non-hormonal treatment like NSAIDs and Tranexamic acid.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Uterine artery embolization: Uterine artery embolization is a surgical option and is considered when other treatments fail.

 

Option B. Endometrial ablation: Endometrial ablation is also a surgical option and should be considered after hormonal therapy.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is the last resort and is used when all other management options fail or are contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective

 

Hormonal therapy, including combined oral contraceptive pills or progesterone-only devices like the LND-IUS, is the next best management step for menorrhagia when non-hormonal management has been ineffective.

 

Ref: Page no 197, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: An 18-month-old baby presents with vesicles on the anterior abdominal wall and forearm, as well as meningitis. A Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells. The mother has a history of genital lesions. What is the likely diagnosis, and what is the causative agent? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HSV 2

 

In this scenario, the 18-month-old baby presents with vesicles on the anterior abdominal wall and forearm, as well as meningitis. The Tzanck smear shows multinucleate giant cells, which are indicative of a herpes virus infection. Given the mother’s history of genital lesions, it is highly suggestive that the baby contracted the infection during delivery.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Vesicles: The presence of vesicles (fluid-filled blisters) is characteristic of herpes infections.
  • Tzanck Smear: This test shows multinucleate giant cells, which are typical findings in herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections.
  • Mother's Genital Lesions: This detail strongly indicates genital herpes, which is most commonly caused by HSV-2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Varicella Zoster: Although varicella zoster virus (VZV) can cause vesicles and multinucleate giant cells, the history of maternal genital lesions and the clinical presentation points more specifically towards HSV.

 

Option C. Enterococcus: This bacterium is not associated with vesicular lesions or multinucleate giant cells on Tzanck smear. It typically causes urinary tract infections, bacteremia, and endocarditis, not the described symptoms.

 

Option D. Toxoplasmosis: Toxoplasmosis can cause congenital infections but does not present with vesicular skin lesions or multinucleate giant cells. The typical findings include intracranial calcifications, chorioretinitis, and hydrocephalus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HSV-2 is a common cause of neonatal herpes, which presents with vesicular lesions and can be confirmed with a Tzanck smear showing multinucleate giant cells. Maternal genital herpes is a significant risk factor for neonatal transmission.
